subNodes.conversationText: root

Knott disappeared, becoming a normal gourd. Pharaoh cawed.

A woman in hunting garb, a quiver of goose-fletched arrows across her back, was pacing in front of the little house. She watched <FirstName> carefully as <he/she> approached.
"Eris," said <FirstName>.
"Do I know you?"
[Continue.]
<FirstName> introduced <him/her>self. <He/She> said <he/she> was a witch and that <he/she> had seen the letter on her door.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> introduced <him/her>self. <He/She> said <he/she> was a witch.
[Continue.]
"A witch?! Then -- Nnenne! Do you know Nnenne? A young woman, very dear to me. Do you know her? Where is she?"
"I am sorry, Eris. Nnenne is dead."

Eris wailed the wail of someone who doesn't often cry, loud and hoarse and pained.

"No, no, no. I knew it -- I knew. She came to me in a dream when I was looking for her. The dream was so sweet that when I woke up I knew. Nothing so good could be true... But no, I didn't know. I guessed, but didn't know. I could still hope. Take it back, please!" she cried, falling to her knees. "Take it back. I had that dream, that dream. That happiness when I woke up. I won't have that again. Nnenne, Nnenne, Nnenne."

She kept repeating the name.
<FirstName> tried to comfort her.
After some time, Eris could no longer sob. The crying had exhausted her. Her eyes were dry and tired. She stood up from where she had been kneeling. She stared disconsolately at the wet ground.
[Continue.]
"How -- how did it happen?"
<FirstName> shook <his/her> head. "It is better for you not to know."
"Why would it matter what she knows or doesn't? She'll be dead soon," said another voice.
[Continue.]

It was Eldest Lady.

Eris froze, spellbound.
"What? Why? I loved her. I want to know what happened to her. I have to know what happened to her."
"Are you sure?" said the young witch, moved and uncertain.
Eris stared hard at <FirstName>. "Was it so awful? Was she in pain?"
[Continue.]
<FirstName> <him/her>self had almost felt Nnenne's pain, but the memory of Nnenne's love for this woman -- and her desire to protect her -- were more intense.
"She felt some pain, but not enough to stop her from thinking about you."
Eris swallowed her tears. "You really won't tell me?"
"I won't. And now you need to know something else -- you're in danger. You need to leave the woods as soon as possible."
"What? In danger? Leave? But where would I go? Does it have something to do with Nnenne?"
"It does, in a way."

Eris was furious. "You tell me nothing! The only person who meant anything to me in the wide world is dead, and you tell me nothing! What way? I'm not a witch! I'm not going to just stand here and take your mysterious directions. Who wants to kill me?"
[Continue.]
Then she gasped. Knott had appeared.
[Continue.]
"What...is...THAT?"
[Continue.]
He lurched toward her.
[Continue.]
Eris took a step back. Her eyes darted from side to side. She was ready to run. She wasn't looking at the witch, only at the creature before her.
[Continue.]

The magic that made Knott urged him to move against this woman, to seek her blood.

But the young witch commanded him to desist. He obeyed, slumping back.
"Leave, Eris. Just leave. Even if it's only for a few days."
"What is this? What's going on?" she spluttered. "A few days? That's all it will take?"
"Yes. If I have anything to do with it."
She looked at Knott standing there grimly. She looked at the young witch. Then she looked at the ground. <FirstName> knew she was thinking of Nnenne.
[Continue.]
"I will do as you say."
[Continue.]
She went into her home, came out with a few things -- including her bow -- and left, not looking back.
Continue
As she left, Knott's eyeless head turned in her direction. He seemed to be watching her the way a mother watches her child begin a long journey.
[End.]
"Today is the witches' sabbath. You will not have as much to fear afterwards."
She looked at Knott standing there grimly. She looked at the young witch. Then she looked at the ground. <FirstName> knew she was thinking of Nnenne.
"Like I said, your life is in danger."
She looked at Knott standing there grimly. She looked at the young witch. Then she looked at the ground. <FirstName> knew she was thinking of Nnenne.
"Not directly. It's the coven."

"The coven? Eldest Lady and Middle One? What did I ever do to them? This makes no sense... You tell me nothing. The only person who meant anything to me in the wide world is dead, and you tell me nothing! In danger? I'm not a witch! I'm not going to just stand here and take your mysterious directions."

Eris was furious.
[Continue.]
"Nnenne wouldn't want you to know."
Eris considered this. "There were so many things she didn't want me to know..."
"You need to hear something else, Eris. You're in danger. You need to leave the woods as soon as possible."
"What? In danger? Leave? But where would I go? Does it have something to do with Nnenne?"
"What she would want you to know is that you're in danger."
"What? In danger? Leave? But where would I go? Does it have something to do with Nnenne?"
"Very well. I will."
<FirstName> began to tell the story. <He/She> explained how Nnenne had taken Eldest Lady's grimoire and cast a spell that transformed into a deer.
"No. She felt nothing. It was very fast."
Eris swallowed her tears. "You really won't tell me?"
"No, you don't, and it's fortunate you don't."
Eris stared hard at <FirstName>. "Was it so awful? Was she in pain?"
"Very well."

But before <FirstName> could say anything, Eldest Lady appeared behind Eris, a dagger drawn.

Eris froze, bewitched.
<FirstName> began to tell the story. <He/She> explained how Nnenne had taken Eldest Lady's grimoire and cast a spell that transformed into a deer.
As painful as it would be, Eris deserved to know the truth.

But before <FirstName> could say anything, Eldest Lady appeared behind Eris, a dagger drawn.

Eris froze, bewitched.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> began to tell the story. <He/She> explained how Nnenne had taken Eldest Lady's grimoire and cast a spell that transformed into a deer.
[Continue.]
Eris's eyes went wide but she said nothing.
[Continue.]
Then <he/she> explained how Nnenne went into the woods to seek a way to turn back.
[Continue.]

"Stop," Eris said. "I know. I know now." She folded her arms across her chest and began to rock herself. "I know what happened. You don't need to keep going. I remember. I remember the deer. I never saw her after that. I never saw her after." The tears returned, redoubled.
<FirstName> knew that comfort was useless.
The young witch looked away.
[Continue.]
"Please. Please. Leave me. Leave me."
[Continue.]
But <FirstName> couldn't do that. <He/She> had something even more important to tell Eris.
"You need to know something else -- you're in danger. You must leave the woods as soon as possible."
She just shook her head. She wasn't listening.
"Nnenne didn't flee to save her own life, but to protect you. Honor her love. Listen to me."

This she heard. She looked up.

Then she gasped.
[Continue.]
Knott was there.
[Continue.]
"Listen to me. Mourn later. Now you must flee."

This she heard. She looked up.

Then she gasped.
"It wasn't your fault. You didn't know. You couldn't have known."
It didn't matter. The dreadful fact made the context meaningless.
"Nnenne didn't flee to save her own life, but to protect you. Honor her love. Listen to me."
"Listen to me. Mourn later. Now you must flee."
"I didn't come here just to tell you this news. You should also know that the coven wants vengeance."
She just shook her head. She wasn't listening.
<FirstName> tried to comfort her.
She shook her head and held up her hands as if to push <FirstName> away.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> waited.
[Continue.]
"You did it."
"What?" she said in disbelief. "What are you talking about?"

But before <FirstName> could say anything, Eldest Lady appeared behind Eris, a dagger drawn.

Eris froze, bewitched.
<FirstName> began to tell the story. <He/She> explained how Nnenne had taken Eldest Lady's grimoire and cast a spell that transformed into a deer.
"A hunter killed her. A hunter who hunts with arrows like the ones in your quiver."
"What?" she was astonished. "One of the other hunters? Who? I'll find them and pay them back. Wait...Why are you looking at me like that? Ah...Goose-fletched arrows. You think I killed her?"
<FirstName> took out the arrow the witches gave him.
"Her blood..." Eris said, her sadness returning.
[Continue.]
She took out one of her own arrows and held it next to the witch's. It matched.
[Continue.]

"I didn't do it. It may look suspicious. But I didn't do it. I loved her. I loved her so much. I loved her life more than my own, and if I thought that being punished for her death would bring her back -- would mean anything -- I would die. Gladly. But I don't believe that."

Then she gasped.
[Continue.]

Knott was suddenly there, towering over them.

He lurched toward the hunter.
[Continue.]
She backed away, her voice quavering. "What...is...THAT?"
[Continue.]
He lunged.
[Continue.]
She began to run.
Continue
Knott followed, his humongous form terrifying in its speed -- a speed that had never been in evidence before. He would have her in seconds.
"No, Knott!" <FirstName> cried. "Stop!"
Knott obeyed.
[Continue.]

Eris, however, kept running. She knew the woods well and was swift of foot, and she was out of sight in seconds.

Knott was still, his eyeless head turned in the direction she had run. He seemed to be watching her the way a parent watches their child begin a long journey.
[End.]
The witch watched and waited.
It took no time at all. Eris was fast and lithe, a skilled hunter, but Knott was a superhuman being, battle-hardened and driven by potent witchcraft.
[Continue.]
She fell to the ground, dead.
[Continue.]
Before <FirstName> could get to the body, Eldest Lady and Middle One appeared.
[Continue.]
"Well, <FirstName> -- better late than never."
[Continue.]
"Not late at all. Too soon. Too soon by far. I am disappointed in our young witch," said Middle One.
[Continue.]

"Don't be foolish, Middle One. My life -- our life -- the coven's life -- They have to go on. If this hunter found out that she'd killed the one she loved, she wouldn't want to go on. It was tragic, but necessary, and for her own good. She's beyond grief now."
"What do you mean? She didn't know she was the killer?"
"A story for another time. It would only confuse you."
[Continue.]

She watched Eris bleed. "What wouldn't I give to die in ignorance of all that I've done?" She looked sad and spoke sadly, but it was impossible to know if she was being sincere; perhaps she didn't know herself. She looked away from the body. ", we'll see you at noon."
"What now?"
Eldest Lady ignored <FirstName>.
[Continue.]

She watched Eris bleed. "What wouldn't I give to die in ignorance of all that I've done?" She looked sad and spoke sadly, but it was impossible to know if she was being sincere; perhaps she didn't know herself. She looked away from the body. ", we'll see you at noon."
[Continue.]
"We will summon you to the binding."
[Continue.]

"I didn't do it. It may look suspicious. But I didn't do it. I loved her. I loved her so much. I loved her life more than my own, and if I thought that being punished for her death would bring her back -- would mean anything -- I would die. Gladly. But I don't believe that."

Then she gasped.
"I know you did. The other two were innocent."
"Were innocent...?" Eris began backing away. Knott began getting larger. Pharaoh cawed.
[Continue.]
Suddenly Eris froze, spellbound.
[Continue.]
Eldest Lady stood behind the paralyzed hunter, a knife in her hand. "Oh, <FirstName>, don't look so surprised. You killed two hunters. Only Eris remained."
[Continue.]

"I didn't do it. It may look suspicious. But I didn't do it. I loved her. I loved her so much. I loved her life more than my own, and if I thought that being punished for her death would bring her back -- would mean anything -- I would die. Gladly. But I don't believe that."

Then she gasped.
"One hunter was innocent. The other -- I don't know. But you knew her."
"Was innocent...?" Eris began backing away. Knott began getting larger. Pharaoh cawed.
[Continue.]
"A hunter living in these woods killed her."
"What?" she was astonished. "One of the other hunters? Who? I'll find them and pay them back. Who was it?"
"They used this," said <FirstName>, taking out the goose-fletched arrow.
She took out one of her own arrows and held it next to the witch's. It matched.
"I don't know." <He/She> thought about the innocent blood <he/she>'d spilled.
This woman was a hunter, and she wore a quiver of goose-fletched arrows. But she, too, seemed innocent.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> took out the goose-fletched arrow.
"I don't know." <He/She > thought about the hunter to the south. Had he been responsible after all?
This woman was a hunter, and she wore a quiver of goose-fletched arrows. But she seemed innocent.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> took out the goose-fletched arrow.
[Continue.]
"I don't know." <He/She > thought about Sudder. Had he been responsible after all?
This woman was a hunter, and she wore a quiver of goose-fletched arrows. But she seemed innocent.
"I don't know." <He/She > thought about the hunters. Had one of them been responsible after all?
This woman was a hunter, and she wore a quiver of goose-fletched arrows. But she seemed innocent.
"I don't know, exactly. I'm searching for the one who did it."
"Do you know anything? Anything at all about who might be responsible?"
"A hunter living in these woods killed her."
"A hunter killed her. A hunter who hunts with arrows like the ones in your quiver."
"They used this," said <FirstName>, taking out the goose-fletched arrow.
<FirstName> waited for the fit to pass.
After some time, Eris could no longer sob. The crying had exhausted her. Her eyes were dry and tired. She stood up from where she had been kneeling. She stared disconsolately at the wet ground.
"Dead. Buried behind Eldest Lady's house."

Eris wailed the wail of someone who doesn't often cry, loud and hoarse and pained.

"No, no, no. I knew it -- I knew. She came to me in a dream when I was looking for her. The dream was so sweet that when I woke up I knew. Nothing so good could be true... But no, I didn't know. I guessed, but didn't know. I could still hope. Take it back, please!" she cried, falling to her knees. "Take it back. I had that dream, that dream. That happiness when I woke up. I won't have that again. Nnenne, Nnenne, Nnenne."

She kept repeating the name.
"I -- do not know," <FirstName> lied. "I only know that she disappeared."

Tears came to the hunter's eyes.

"How do you know about her? How did you find out she was missing? Do you have any news?"
"No...Nothing. Only that she's been gone for a little over a month."
"I've tried so hard to find her. Scoured the woods. Went back to the place she came from. Looked for the witches' house...They don't know anything either? The witches?"
"No. They are at a loss too."
"Well, not completely at a loss," said a voice.
[Continue.]

It was Eldest Lady.

Eris froze, spellbound.
[Continue.]
The old witch stood behind the paralyzed hunter, a knife in her hand.
[Continue.]

Middle One was there too.

"Please, sister. Don't. Don't."
[Continue.]

"Don't be foolish, Middle One. My life -- our life -- the coven's life -- They have to go on. If this hunter found out that she'd killed the one she loved, she wouldn't want to go on. It's tragic, but necessary, and it's for her own good. She'll feel no pain -- physically or otherwise."
"What do you mean? She didn't know she was the killer?"
"A story for another time. It would only confuse you."
"Very well. Give me the knife. This is my test."
"No, young witch," Eldest Lady said. "I know you don't trust me."
"Put the knife down, Eldest Lady. If she didn't kill Nnenne on purpose, she shouldn't die."
"No, young witch," Eldest Lady said. "I know you don't trust me."
"This is my test. I will do it," <FirstName> said, motioning for the knife.
"No, young witch," Eldest Lady said. "I know you don't trust me."
[Continue.]
The knife was as fast as a snake. The strike was fluid, as if routine.
[Continue.]

"And I don't trust you."

Eris crumpled to the ground.
[Continue.]
Middle One cried out. "Terrible, terrible woman."
[Continue.]

"I am terrible, Middle One. Ruthless and terrible. I am old, and that is what being as old as I am does to you." She watched Eris bleed. "What wouldn't I give to die in ignorance of all that I've done?" She looked sad and spoke sadly, but it was impossible to know if she was being sincere; perhaps she didn't know herself. She looked away from the body. ", we'll see you at noon."
"I want nothing to do with your coven."
"Too late for that. This blood makes the coven whole. These woods are ours, and they will not let you leave. You will have no choice but to come to us at the proper time."
[Continue.]
"Too late for that. This blood will make the coven whole. These woods are ours, and they will not let you leave. You will have no choice but to come to us at the proper time."
[Continue.]
"Where will we three meet?"
"Our power will bring you to the place."
[Continue.]
Eldest Lady and Middle One vanished. Eris's body did too. <FirstName> was alone except for Knott and Pharaoh.
Everything had gone wrong.
<His/Her> own bloody work had made it so.
[Continue.]
What more would <he/she> have to do?
[End.]
Everything was going according to Eldest Lady's plan.
<FirstName> wished <he/she> had one of <his/her> own.
[End.]
"This blood helps make the coven whole. Our power will bring you to the place."
[Continue.]
"Listen to Middle One, Eldest Lady. Put the dagger down."
"No, young witch," Eldest Lady said. "I know you don't trust me."
"I see... Why are you here?"
"I'm here to warn you. You're in danger. You should leave the woods as soon as you can."
"And go where? Wait -- You're serious, aren't you? But how? Does it have something to do with Nnenne?"
"It does, in a way."
"If you know something, tell me! I have been tearing my heart out looking for her."
"It's not that. Eldest Lady knows you and Nnenne were close. She thinks you have something to do with her disappearance."
"That's preposterous. And because of this suspicion, she is going to hunt me down and kill me?"
"Yes. I'm sure Nnenne told you what Eldest Lady is like."
"I would like to have a few words with that tyrant of a woman."
"Do so at your peril. There will be no discussion."
Eris considered <FirstName>. She shook her head.
[Continue.]
"There's a great deal you're not telling me."
[Continue.]
Pharaoh cawed.
[Continue.]
"If your bird could talk, he would tell me more."
[Continue.]

Her shoulders slumped.

"Fine. Nnenne hasn't come back. I'll look for her. Head east this time. Maybe I'll find her, and we can leave these woods and Eldest Lady's wrath behind."
[Continue.]
"Tell me one thing, though -- I know you're a witch, but what do you have to do with the coven? I know there can't be more than three in it."
"That's true. I'm just sort of -- entangled with them."
Eris raised an eyebrow but said nothing. She went into her home, came out with a few things -- including her bow -- and left, not looking back.
[Continue.]

Knott turned back into himself once there was no danger of her seeing him. His eyeless head was turned in the direction she'd taken. He seemed to be watching her go the way a mother watches her child begin a long journey.
[End.]
"They consider me their conscience."
Eris raised an eyebrow but said nothing. She went into her home, came out with a few things -- including her bow -- and left, not looking back.
"Please, just listen to me. Leave. Even if it's just for a few days."
"A few days? Is she going to give up so quickly?"
"Yes, if I have anything to do with it."
Eris considered <FirstName>. She shook her head.
"Perhaps, perhaps not. But today is our sabbath. It is a very dangerous time."
Eris considered <FirstName>. She shook her head.
"Life is very cheap to some witches."
"I would like to have a few words with that tyrant of a woman."
"Or worse."
"Well, I've wanted to talk to them for weeks. Maybe they know something that could help me find Nnenne. I'm not scared of them. I'll wait for them right here."
"Do so at your peril. There will be no discussion."
"Please, just listen to me. Leave. Even if it's just for a few days."
<FirstName> couldn't keep up the lie. <He/She> told Eris Nnenne was dead.
"Not directly. It's the coven."
"The coven? Eldest Lady and Middle One? What have I done to them?"
"It's not that. Eldest Lady knows you and Nnenne were close. She thinks you have something to do with her disappearance."
<FirstName> couldn't keep up the lie. <He/She> told Eris Nnenne was dead.
<FirstName> couldn't keep up the lie. <He/She> told Eris Nnenne was dead.

Eris wailed the wail of someone who doesn't often cry, loud and hoarse and pained.

"No, no, no. I knew it -- I knew. She came to me in a dream when I was looking for her. The dream was so sweet that when I woke up I knew. Nothing so good could be true... But no, I didn't know. I guessed, but didn't know. I could still hope. Take it back, please!" she cried, falling to her knees. "Take it back. I had that dream, that dream. That happiness when I woke up. I won't have that again. Nnenne, Nnenne, Nnenne."

She kept repeating the name.
"I am just passing by."
"In my experience, a witch is never just passing by. They always have some purpose in mind, some strange thing they want for themselves or for someone else."
"You've learned a lot from Nnenne."
The hunter's expression turned sad again. "Yes -- Yes, I have... So, what's your secret purpose?"
"You're in danger. I have to make you leave the forest."
"And go where? Wait -- You're serious, aren't you? But how? Does it have something to do with Nnenne?"
[Continue.]
Then she gasped.
[Continue.]
"It's true... You're in danger, Eris. You should leave the woods as soon as you can."
"And go where? Wait -- You're serious, aren't you? But how? Does it have something to do with Nnenne?"
<FirstName> couldn't keep up the lie. <He/She> told Eris Nnenne was dead.
<FirstName> couldn't keep up the lie. <He/She> told Eris Nnenne was dead.
<FirstName> couldn't keep up the lie. <He/She> told Eris Nnenne was dead.
"You're Eris. I recognize you."
"Recognize me? From where? I don't think we've met."
[Continue.]
"You must be Eris," said <FirstName>, approaching her.
"Do I know you?"
The young witch introduced <him/her>self.
The woman introduced herself as Eris. She looked at Pharaoh as she talked.
[Continue.]
"That crow -- Is that your familiar? Are you a witch?"
[Continue.]
<FirstName> acknowledged that <he/she> was.
[Continue.]
"Then -- Nnenne! Do you know Nnenne? A young woman, very dear to me. Do you know her? Where is she?"
"I am sorry, Eris. Nnenne is dead."
"Dead. Buried behind Eldest Lady's house."
"I -- do not know," <FirstName> lied. "I only know that she disappeared."
